body_html:
Code 139 is attempt to access a virtual address which is not in your address space, which would support a memory allocation error, which could happen easily if you are on 32-bit system

SIGSEGV is a hard crash of the process do to an invalid memory access in native code, it has no chance to signal that to the multiprocessing host.
It should throw an exception on its own, is that not happening?

Code 139 is attempt to access a virtual address which is not in your address space, which would support a memory allocation error, which could happen easily if you are on 32-bit system
SIGSEGV is a hard crash of the process do to an invalid memory access in native code, it has no chance to signal that to the multiprocessing host.
It should throw an exception on its own, is that not happening?
body:
Code 139 is attempt to access a virtual address which is not in your address space, which would support a memory allocation error, which could happen easily if you are on 32-bit system 

SIGSEGV is a hard crash of the process do to an invalid memory access in native code, it has no chance to signal that to the multiprocessing host.
It should throw an exception on its own, is that not happening?
